newsitem.title: USA: Robert Downey Jr. put on probation on drug charges.
newsitem.headline: Robert Downey Jr. put on probation on drug charges.

text.p: Actor Robert Downey Jr. was sentenced on Wednesday to three years' probation, having pleaded no contest to possessing cocaine and heroin, carrying a concealed weapon, and driving under the influence of drugs.
Judge Lawrence Mira also ordered him to remain in a live-in drug rehabilitation programme for another three months, submit to periodic drug and alcohol tests and pay $250 in fees and restitution.
Mira told the Oscar-nominated actor, "If you've ever had a chance here to deal with this problem and maintain your sobriety, this is the chance you're going to get.
"I wish you good luck. You've made a good start," the judge added.

Downey, nominated for an Oscas for his role as Charlie Chaplin in the film "Chaplin," has been in the drug rehabilitation programme for three months. Prosecutors in the case did not seek a prison term.
Outside the courtroom Downey's attorney, Charles English, told reporters his client "couldn't be doing better, but he realises he's got a long way to go."
He said Downey felt bad about what happened. "He feels bad that he let the public and some of his fans down," he said.

Downey pleaded no contest to the charges, California's equivalent of pleading guilty, in September. He was stopped for speeding on June 23 and police found cocaine, heroin and a pistol in the back of the pickup truck he was driving.

Downey was arrested again in July for entering a stranger's home in Malibu, where he was found asleep in a child's bedroom. He was back behind bars three days later for leaving a live-in drug rehabilitation centre a judge had ordered him to attend as a condition of releasing him on bail on the drug and gun charges.

The 31-year-old actor, son of filmmaker Robert Downey, played a cocaine addict in the 1987 movie "Less Than Zero" and more recently starred in such films as "The Last Party," "Short Cuts," "Natural Born Killers" and "Only You."
